name: Mishmi Takin
description: It has a sturdy, bear-like head, distinctively shaped horns (present in both males and females), and long, wavy fur that excellently protects it in harsh mountain conditions.
spread_note: From northern Tibet to central and southern China
proportions: Body length 100–240 cm, tail length 7–15 cm, shoulder height 70–140 cm, weight 150–400 kg
attractions: They regularly migrate between summer pastures above the treeline and winter shelters in protected forested mountain valleys. In summer, they form large herds of up to 300 individuals, which break into smaller groups of about 20 in winter.
breeding: Takins are rarely kept in zoos. The first pair arrived in Prague in 1998 from Berlin Zoo. The male died in late 2000, but the female gave birth to a female calf in March 2001—the first takin born in a Czech zoo.
